Titre: Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 054°)
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 054°)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision , the vessel (vessel A) which has the other (vessel B) on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), vessel A shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the vessel B.
Commentaires: Crossing situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel is approaching the other vessel from a direction right ahead to 112,5° on any side of the vessel except when vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses. In crossing situation at night a vessel would be able to see only green or red sidelight and masthead light (s) of the other vessel.

Titre: Head-on situation (vessels are meeting on reciprocal courses)
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is meeting vessel B on reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B right ahead (relative bearing 000°)
Reference_Regle: Rule 14 (Head-on situation) Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 14 (b) (Head-on situation), head-on situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel A sees the other (vessel B) ahead and by night she could see the masthead lights of the other in a line and/or both sidelights and by day she observes the corresponding aspect of the other vessel. In accordance with Rule 14 (a) (Head-on situation), when two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision each shall alter her course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other. In accordance with Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel), vessels A and B which are both directed to keep out of the way of each other shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

Titre: A power-driven vessel under 7 m and maximum speed up to 7 knots underway - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel of less than 7 m in length whose maximum speed does not exceed 7 knots underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 23 (d)(iii) (Power-driven vessels underway ), the masthead light or all-round white light on a power driven vessel of less than 12 m in length may be displaced from the fore and aft centerline of the vessel if centerline fitting is not practicable, provided the sidelights are combined in one lantern which shall be carried on the fore and aft centerline of the vessel or located as nearly as practicable in the same fore and aft line as the masthead light or all-round white light.

Titre: A sailing vessel underway - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 25 (a) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 25 (a) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars), a sailing vessel underway shall exhibit: (i) sidelights ; (ii) a sternlight .

Titre: A sailing vessel underway - additional two all-round lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 25 (c) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars), a sailing vessel underway may, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 25 (a) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars) exhibit at or near the top of the mast, where they can best be seen, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower green, but these lights shall not be exhibited in conjunction with the combined lantern permitted by Rule 25 (b) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars).

Titre: A sailing vessel under 20 m underway - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel of less than 20 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 25 (b) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars), in a sailing vessel underway of less than 20 metres in length the lights prescribed in Rule 25 (a) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars) may be combined in one lantern at or near the top of the mast where it can best be seen.

Titre: A vessel proceeding under sail when also being propelled by machinery - shapes
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel proceeding under sail when also being propelled by machinery Time of the day: Daytime
Reference_Regle: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 25 (e) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars), a vessel proceeding under sail when also being propelled by machinery shall exhibit forward where it can best be seen a conical shape, apex downwards.

Titre: A sailing vessel under 7 m underway - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel of less than 7 m in legth underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 25 (d) (i) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars), a sailing vessel underway of less than 7 m in length shall, if practicable, exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 25 (a) or (b) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars), but if she does not, she shall have ready to hand an electric torch or lighted lantern showing a white light which shall be exhibited in sufficient time to prevent a collision.

Titre: A vessel under oars - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel under oars Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 25 (d)(ii) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars), a vessel under oars may exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 25 (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars) for sailing vessels, but if she does not, she may have ready at hand an electric torch or lighted lantern showing a white light which shall be exhibited in sufficient time to prevent collision.

Titre: A vessel engaged in trawling when making way through the water - lights

Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 26 (a) (Fishing vessels), a vessel engaged in fishing , whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26 (Fishing vessels). In accordance with Rule 26 (b) (Fishing vessels), a vessel when engaged in trawling, by which is meant the dragging through the water of a dredge net or other apparatus used as a fishing appliance, shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white; (ii) a masthead light abaft of and higher that the all-round green light; (iii) sidelights and a sternlight . In accordance with Rule 26 (b) (ii) (Fishing vessels), a vessel of less than 50 metres in length shall not be obliged to exhibit a masthead light but may do so.

In accordance with Rule 26 (b) (ii) (Fishing vessels), a vessel of less than 50 m in length shall not be obliged to exhibit a masthead light but may do so.

Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 26 (a) (Fishing vessels), a vessel engaged in fishing , whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26 (Fishing vessels). In accordance with Rule 26 (b) (Fishing vessels), a vessel when engaged in trawling, by which is meant the dragging through the water of a dredge net or other apparatus used as a fishing appliance, shall exhibit: (i) a shape consisting of two cones with their apexes together in a vertical line one above the other.

Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 26 (a) (Fishing vessels), a vessel engaged in fishing , whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26 (Fishing vessels). Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing , other than trawling (when the outlying gear does not extend more than 150 metres horizontally from the vessel) Time of the day: Daytime

Titre: A vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling with outlying gear extending more than 150 m - shapes
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing , other than trawling when there is outlying gear extending more than 150 m horizontally from the vessel Time of the day: Daytime

Titre: A vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling with outlying gear extending more than 150 m when not making way through the water - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing , other than trawling when there is outlying gear extending more than 150 m horizontally from the vessel, when not making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

Titre: A vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling with outlying gear extending more than 150 m when making way through the water - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing , other than trawling when there is outlying gear extending more than 150 m horizontally from the vessel when making way thorugh the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility

Reference_Regle: Rule 28 (Vessels constrained by their draught) Rule 23 (Power-driven vessels underway )
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 28 (Vessels constrained by their draught), a vessel constrained by her draught may, in addition to the lights prescribed for power-driven vessels in Rule 23 (Power-driven vessels underway ), exhibit where they can best be seen three all-round red lights in a vertical line. Reference_Regle: Rule 28 (Vessels constrained by their draught) Rule 23 (Power-driven vessels underway )
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 28 (Vessels constrained by their draught), a vessel constrained by her draught may, in addition to the lights prescribed for power-driven vessels in Rule 23 (Power-driven vessels underway ), exhibit where they can best be seen three all-round red lights in a vertical line. Titre: A vessel constrained by her draught underway - shapes
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel constrained by her draught underway Time of the day: Daytime
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 28 (Vessels constrained by their draught), a vessel constrained by her draught may exhibit where it can best be seen a cylinder.

Titre: A vessel engaged on pilotage duty underway - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged on pilotage duty underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 29 (a) (Pilot vessels), a vessel engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit: (i) at or near the masthead, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being white and the lower red; (ii) sidelights and a sternlight .

Titre: A vessel engaged on pilotage duty under 50 m at anchor - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged on pilotage duty of less than 50 m in length at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 29 (Pilot vessels) Rule 30 (Anchored vessels and vessels aground)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 29 (a) (Pilot vessels), a vessel engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit: (i) at or near the masthead, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being white and the lower red; (iii) the lights prescribed in Rule 30 (Anchored vessels and vessels aground) for vessels at anchor. In accordance with Rule 30 (b) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel of less than 50 m in length may exhibit an all-round white light where it can best be seen instead of the lights prescribed in Rule 30 (a) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground).

Titre: A vessel under 50 m at anchor - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 50 m in length at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 30 (b) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel of less than 50 m in length may exhibit an all-round white light where it can best be seen instead of the lights prescribed in Rule 30 (a) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground).

Titre: A vessel under 7 m at anchor - lights
Scenario: Area: All areas but not in or near a narrow channel , fairway or anchorage, or where other vessels normally navigate Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 7 m in length at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 30 (e) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel of less than 7 m in length, when at anchor, not in or near a narrow channel , fairway or anchorage, or where other vessels normally navigate, shall not be required to exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 30 (a) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground) and Rule 30 (b) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground).

Titre: A vessel over 50 m and under 100 m at anchor - lights

Titre: A vessel over 100 m at anchor - lights

In accordance with Rule 30 (c) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel of 100 m and more in length at anchor shall, also use the available working or equivalent lights to illuminate her decks.

Titre: A vessel aground - shapes

Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 30 (d) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel aground shall exhibit, where they can best be seen: (ii) three balls in a vertical line.

Titre: A vessel under 50 m aground - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 50 m aground Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 30 (d) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel aground shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 30 (b) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground) and in addition, where they can best be seen: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line.
Commentaires: A vessel aground of less than 50 m in length shall exhibit: - an all-round white light, where it can best be seen; - two all-round red lights in a vertical line, where they can best be seen.

Titre: A vessel over 50 m aground - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of more than 50 m in length aground Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 30 (d) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel aground shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 30 (a) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground) and in addition, where they can best be seen: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line.
Commentaires: A vessel aground of more than 50 m in length shall exhibit: - in the fore part, an all-round white light; - at or near the stern and at a lower level that the light in the fore part, an all-round white light; - two all-round red lights in a vertical line, where they can best be seen.

Titre: Vessels are meeting on reciprocal courses
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is meeting vessel B on reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B right ahead (relative bearing 000°)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 14 (b) (Head-on situation), head-on situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel (vessel A) sees the other (vessel B) ahead and by night she could see the masthead lights of the other in a line and/or both sidelights and by day she observes the corresponding aspect of the other vessel. In accordance with Rule 14 (c) (Head-on situation), when a vessel is in any doubt as to whether such a situation exists she shall assume that it does exist and act accordingly.

Titre: Vessels are meeting on nearly reciprocal courses (vessel A has vessel B on STBD bow)
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is meeting vessel B on nearly reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B nearly ahead on STBD bow
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 14 (b) (Head-on situation), head-on situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel (vessel A) sees the other (vessel B) nearly ahead and by night she could see the masthead lights of the other nearly in a line and/or both sidelights and by day she observes the corresponding aspect of the other vessel. In accordance with Rule 14 (c) (Head-on situation), when a vessel is in any doubt as to whether such a situation exists she shall assume that it does exist and act accordingly.

Titre: Exhibiting lights from sunset to sunrise
Scenario: Visibility: Good Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 20 (b) (Application), the rules concerning lights shall be complied with from sunset to sunrise, and during such times no other lights shall be exhibited, except such lights as cannot be mistaken for the lights specified in these Rules or do not impair their visibility or distinctive character, or interfere with the keeping of a proper look-out . In accordance with Rule 20 (e) (Application), the lights specified in these Rules shall comply with the provisions of Annex 1 to these Regulations.

Titre: Exhibiting shapes during the daytime
Scenario: Time of the day: Daytime
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 20 (d) (Application), the rules concerning shapes shall be complied with by day.
Commentaires: Daytime means from sunrise to sunset. In accordance with Rule 20 (e) (Application), shapes specified in these Rules shall comply with the provisions of Annex 1 to these Regulations.

Titre: Exhibiting lights in restricted visibility
Scenario: Visibility: Restricted Time of the day: From sunrise to sunset
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 20 (c) (Application), the lights prescribed by these Rules shall, if carried, also be exhibited from sunrise to sunset inrestricted visibility and may be exhibited in all other circumstances when it is deemed necessary. In accordance with Rule 20 (e) (Application), the lights specified in these Rules shall comply with the provisions of Annex 1 to these Regulations.

Titre: The additional signals apply to a vessel engaged in fishing in close proximity to other vessels engaged in fishing
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing in close proximity to other vessels engaged in fishing
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 26 (a) (Fishing vessels), a vessel engaged in fishing , whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26 (Fishing vessels). In accordance with Rule 26 (d) (Fishing vessels), a vessel engaged in fishing in close proximity to other vessel engaged in fishing may exhibit the additional signals described in Annex II to these Regulations.

Titre: Fishing vessel not engaged in fishing
Scenario: Type of vessel: Fishing vessel not engaged in fishing
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 26 (e) (Fishing vessels), a vessel when not engaged in fishing shall not exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed in Rule 26 (Fishing vessels), but only those prescribed for a vessel of her length.

Titre: Sound signals and supplemental light signals when altering course to starboard
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to starboard (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by one short blast on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to starboard (vessel A) may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by one flash. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the duration of flash shall be about one second and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(iii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles, and shall comply with the provisions of Annex I to these Regulations. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals when altering course to starboard
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to starboard (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by one short blast on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals and supplemental light signals when altering course to port
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to port (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by two short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to port (vessel A) may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by two flashes. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(iii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles, and shall comply with the provisions of Annex I to these Regulations. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals when altering course to port
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to port (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by two short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals and supplemental light signals when operating astern propulsion
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by three short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by three flashes. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(iii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles, and shall comply with the provisions of Annex I to these Regulations. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals when operating astern propulsion
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by three short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals in narrow channel or fairway to indicate intention to overtake another vessel on her starboard side
Scenario: Vessel A: Vessel about to be overtaken Vessel B: Vessel intending to overtake another vessel Area: Narrow channel of fairway Vessels are in sight of one another
Reference_Regle: Rule 34 (Manoeuvring and warning signals) Rule 9 ( Narrow Channels )
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), when in sight of one another in a narrow channel or fairway a vessel intending to overtake (vessel B) another vessel (vessel A) on her starboard side shall in compliance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow Channels ) indicate her intention by two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the vessel about to be overtaken (vessel A) when acting in accordance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow Channels ) shall indicate her agreement by one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast on her whistle , in that order. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals in narrow channel or fairway to indicate intention to overtake another vessel on her port side
Scenario: Vessel A: Vessel about to be overtaken Vessel B: Vessel intending to overtake another vessel Area: Narrow channel of fairway Vessels are in sight of one another
Reference_Regle: Rule 34 (Manoeuvring and warning signals) Rule 9 ( Narrow Channels )
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), when in sight of one another in a narrow channel or fairway a vessel intending to overtake (vessel B) another vessel (vessel A) on her port side shall in compliance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow Channels ) indicate her intention by two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the vessel about to be overtaken (vessel A) when acting in accordance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow Channels ) shall indicate her agreement by one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast on her whistle , in that order. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals when intentions of approaching vessel are unclear
Scenario: Vessel A fails to understand the intentions or actions of vessel B Vessels are in sight of one another
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (d) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), when vessels in sight of one another are approaching each other and from any cause either vessel fails to understand the intentions or actions of the other vessel, or is in doubt whether sufficient action is being taken by the other to avoid collision, the vessel in doubt (vesel A) shall immediately indicate such doubt by giving at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals and supplemental light signals when intentions of approaching vessel are unclear
Scenario: Vessel A fails to understand the intentions or actions of vessel B Vessels are in sight of one another
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (d) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), when vessels in sight of one another are approaching each other and from any cause either vessel fails to understand the intentions or actions of the other vessel, or is in doubt whether sufficient action is being taken by the other to avoid collision, the vessel in doubt (vessel A) shall immediately indicate such doubt by giving at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (d) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), sound signals may be supplemented by a light signal of at least five short and rapid flashes. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals when other vessel may be obscured by an intervening obstruction
Scenario: Area: Near a bend or an area of a channel or a fairway where other vessel may be obscured by an intervening obstruction
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 34 (e) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel nearing a bend or an area of the channel of fairway where other vessels may be obscured by an intervening obstruction shall sound one prolonged blast . Such signal shall be answered with a prolonged blast by any approaching vessel that may be within hearing around the bend or behind the intervening obstruction. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Titre: Sound signals of a power-driven vessel making way through the water in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel making way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (a) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a power-driven vessel making way through the water shall sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes one prolonged blast .

Titre: Sound signals of a power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way through the water in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (b) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way through the water shall sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes two prolonged blasts in succession with an interval of about 2 seconds between them.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel not under command in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel not under command Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (c) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel not under command shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (a) or (b) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (c) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (a) or (b) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel constrained by her draught in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel constrained by her draught Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (c) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel constrained by her draught shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (a) or (b) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.

Titre: Sound signals of a sailing vessel in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (c) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a sailing vessel shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (a) or (b) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel engaged in fishing in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (c) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel engaged in fishing shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (a) or (b) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel engaged in fishing, when at anchor, in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in fishing , when at anchor Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (d) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel engaged in fishing , when at anchor, shall instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ) sound the signal prescribed in Rule 35 (c) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ).
Commentaires: A vessel engaged in fishing , when at anchor, shall sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when carrying out her work at anchor in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when carrying out her work at anchor Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (d) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when carrying out her work at anchor shall instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ) sound the signal prescribed in Rule 35 (c) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ).
Commentaires: A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when carrying out her work at anchor, shall sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.

Titre: Sound signals of vessels engaged in towing operation in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Towing vessel and vessel being towed Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (c) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel engaged in towing another vessel shall, instead of the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (a) or (b) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), sound at intervals of not more that 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts. In accordance with Rule 35 (e) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel towed or if more that one vessel is towed the last vessel of the tow, if manned, shall at intervals of not more than 2 minutes sound four blasts in succession, namely one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts. When practicable, this signal shall be made immediately after the signal made by the towing vessel.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel under 100 m at anchor in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel at anchor of less than 100 m in length Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel at anchor shall at intervals of not more than one minute ring the bell rapidly for about 5 seconds. In accordance with Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel at anchor may in addition sound three blasts in succession, namely one short, one prolonged and one short blast , to give warning of her position and of the possibility of collision to an approaching vessel.

Titre: Sound signals of vessels engaged in pushing operation when rigidly connected in a composite unit and making way through the water in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Pushing vessel and vessel being pushed ahead rigidly connected in a composited unit making way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (f) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), when a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and shall give the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (a) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ).
Commentaires: When a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit and making way through the water they shall sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes one prolonged blast .

Titre: Sound signals of vessels engaged in pushing operation when rigidly connected in a composite unit underway but stopped and making no way through the water in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Pushing vessel and vessel being pushed ahead rigidly connected in a composite unit underway but stopped and making no way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (f) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), when a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and shall give the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (b) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ).
Commentaires: When a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit and underway but stopped and making no way through the water they shall sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes two prolonged blasts in succession with an interval of about 2 seconds between them.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel over 100 m at anchor in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel at anchor of 100 m or more in length Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel at anchor shall at intervals of not more than one minute ring the bell rapidly for about 5 seconds. In accordance with Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), in a vessel of 100 metres of more in length the bell shall be sounded in the forepart of the vessel and immediately after the ringing of the bell the gong shall be sounded rapidly for about 5 seconds in the after part of the vessel. In accordance with Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel at anchor may in addition sound three short blasts in succession, namely one short, one prolonged and one short blast , to give warning of her position and of the possibility of collision to an approaching vessel.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel aground under 100 m in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel aground of less than 100 m in length Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (h) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel aground shall give the bell signal prescribed in Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ) and shall, in addition, give three separate and distinct strokes on the bell immediately before and after the rapid ringing of the bell. In accordance with Rule 35 (h) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel aground may in addition sound an appropriate whistle signal.
Commentaires: A vessel aground of less than 100 m in length shall at intervals of not more than one minute give three separate and distinct strokes on the bell, followed by rapidly ringing on the bell for about 5 seconds and another three separate and distinct strokes on the bell.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel aground over 100 m in restricted visibility
Scenario: Vessel aground of 100 m or more in length Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (h) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel aground shall give the bell signal and the gong signal prescribed in Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ) and shall, in addition, give three separate and distinct strokes on the bell immediately before and after the rapid ringing of the bell. In accordance with Rule 35 (h) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel aground may in addition sound an appropriate whistle signal.
Commentaires: A vessel aground of 100 m or more in length shall at intervals of not more than one minute give three separate and distinct strokes on the bell, followed by rapidly ringing on the bell for about 5 seconds and another three separate and distinct strokes on the bell at the forepart of the vessel and immediately after the ringing of the bell the gong shall be sounded rapidly for about 5 seconds in the after part of the vessel.

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel over 12 m and under 20 m at anchor in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of 12 m or more but less than 20 m in length at anchor Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (i) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel of 12 m or more but less than 20 m in length shall not be obliged to give the bell signals prescribed in Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ). However, if she does not, she shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.
Commentaires: As a vessel of 12 m or more but less than 20 m in length is obliged to carry a whistle only, an efficient sound signal may be sounded by a whistle .

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel under 12 m in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 12 m in length Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (j) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel of less than 12 m in length shall not be obliged to give the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (g) and (h) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ) but, if she does not, shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more that 2 minutes.
Commentaires: As a vessel of less than 12 m in length is not obliged to carry a whistle , a bell or gong, an efficient sound signal may be sounded by some other means of making an efficient sound signal.

Titre: Masthead light
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 21 (a) (Definitions), " masthead light " means a white light placed over the fore and aft centre line of the vessel showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 225° and so fixed as to show the light from right ahead to 22.5° abaft the beam on either side of the vessel.
Commentaires: Masthead lights are sometimes called “steaming lights” because they are only placed on power-driven vessels.

Titre: Sidelights
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 21 (b) (Definitions), " sidelights " means a green light on the starboard side and a red light on the port side each showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 112.5° and so fixed as to show the light from right ahead to 22.5° abaft the beam on its respective side.

Titre: Sidelights in vessels under 20 m
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessels of less than 20 m in length Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 21 (b) (Definitions), " sidelights " means a green light on the starboard side and a red light on the port side each showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 112.5° and so fixed as to show the light from right ahead to 22.5° abaft the beam on its respective side. In accordance with Rule 21 (b) (Definitions), in a vessel of less than 20 m in length the sidelights may be combined in one lantern carried on the fore-and-aft centreline of the vessel.

Titre: Sternlight
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 21 (c) (Definitions), " sternlight " means a white light placed as nearly as practicable at the stern showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 135° and so fixed as to show the light 67.5° from right aft on each side of the vessel.
Commentaires: Sternlight is sometimes called “overtaking light” because it exactly matches the overtaking sector defined in Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking).

Titre: Towing light
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 21 (d) (Definitions), " towing light " means a yellow light having the same characteristics as the " sternlight " defined in Rule 21 (c) (Definitions).
Commentaires: Towing light shall be placed as nearly as practicable at the stern showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 135° and so fixed as to show the light 67.5° from right aft on each side of the vessel.

Titre: All-round light
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 21 (e) (Definitions), " all-round light" means a light showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 360°.
Commentaires: All-round lights may be white, green and red.

Titre: Flashing light
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 21 (f) (Definitions), " flashing light " means a light flashing at regular intervals at a frequency of 120 flashes or more per minute.
Commentaires: Flashing lights may be yellow and red.

Titre: Visibility of lights in vessels over 50 m
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility Type of vessel: Vessels of 50 m or more in length
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 22 (a) (Visibility of lights), the lights in vessels of 50 m or more in length shall be visible at the following minimum ranges: - a masthead light , 6 miles; - a sidelight , 3 miles; - a sternlight , 3 miles; - a towing light , 3 miles; - a white, red, green or yellow all-round light, 3 miles. In accordance with Rule 22 (Visibility of lights), the lights prescribed in these Regulations shall have an intensity as specified in section 8 of annex I to these Regulations.

Titre: Visibility of lights in vessels over 20 m and under 50 m
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility Type of vessel: Vessels of 20 m or more in length but less than 50 m in length
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 22 (b) (Visibility of lights), the lights in vessels of 20 m or more in length but less than 50 m in length shall be visible at the following minimum ranges: - a masthead light , 5 miles; - a sidelight , 2 miles; - a sternlight , 2 miles; - a towing light , 2 miles; - a white, red, green or yellow all-round light, 2 miles. In accordance with Rule 22 (Visibility of lights), the lights prescribed in these Regulations shall have an intensity as specified in section 8 of annex I to these Regulations.

Titre: Visibility of lights in vessels over 12 m and under 20 m
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility Type of vessel: Vessels of 12 m or more in length but less than 20 m in length
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 22 (b) (Visibility of lights), the lights in vessels of 12 m or more in length but less than 20 m in length shall be visible at the following minimum ranges: - a masthead light , 3 miles; - a sidelight , 2 miles; - a sternlight , 2 miles; - a towing light , 2 miles; - a white, red, green or yellow all-round light, 2 miles. In accordance with Rule 22 (Visibility of lights), the lights prescribed in these Regulations shall have an intensity as specified in section 8 of annex I to these Regulations.

Titre: Visibility of lights in inconspicuous, partly submerged vessels or objects being towed
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility Type of vessel: Inconspicuous, partly submerged vessels or objects being towed
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 22 (d) (Visibility of lights), the lights in inconspicuous, partly submerged vessels or objects being towed shall be visible at the following minimum ranges: - a white all-round light, 3 miles. In accordance with Rule 22 (Visibility of lights), the lights prescribed in these Regulations shall have an intensity as specified in section 8 of annex I to these Regulations.

Titre: Visibility of lights in vessels under 12 m
Scenario: Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility Type of vessel: Vessels of less than 12 m in length
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 22 (c) (Visibility of lights), the lights in vessels of less than 12 m in length shall be visible at the following minimum ranges: - a masthead light , 2 miles; - a sidelight , 1 miles; - a sternlight , 2 miles; - a towing light , 2 miles; - a white, red, green or yellow all-round light, 2 miles. In accordance with Rule 22 (Visibility of lights), the lights prescribed in these Regulations shall have an intensity as specified in section 8 of annex I to these Regulations.

Titre: Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 053°)
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 053°)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision , the vessel (vessel B) which has the other (vessel A) on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), vessel B shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the vessel A.
Commentaires: Crossing situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel is approaching the other vessel from a direction right ahead to 112,5° on any side of the vessel except when vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses. In crossing situation at night a vessel would be able to see only green or red sidelight and masthead light (s) of the other vessel.

Titre: Vessels are meeting on nearly reciprocal courses (vessel A has vessel B on PORT bow)
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is meeting vessel B on nearly reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B nearly ahead on PORT bow
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 14 (b) (Head-on situation), head-on situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel (vessel A) sees the other (vessel B) nearly ahead and by night she could see the masthead lights of the other nearly in a line and/or both sidelights and by day she observes the corresponding aspect of the other vessel. In accordance with Rule 14 (c) (Head-on situation), when a vessel is in any doubt as to whether such a situation exists she shall assume that it does exist and act accordingly.

Titre: Relative bearing of overtaking vessel is STBD 130°
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 130°)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B because she is coming up with vessel B from a direction more than 22.5° abaft her beam. In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A is in such a position with reference to the vessel she is overtaking (vessel B), that at night she (vessel A) would be able to see only the sternlight of vessel B but neither of her sidelights . In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B).

Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 160°)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B because she is coming up with vessel B from a direction more than 22.5° abaft her beam. In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A is in such a position with reference to the vessel she is overtaking (vessel B), that at night she (vessel A) would be able to see only the sternlight of vessel B but neither of her sidelights . In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B).

Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B Vessel A is astern of vessel B (relative bearing 180°)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B because she is coming up with vessel B from a direction more than 22.5° abaft her beam. In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A is in such a position with reference to the vessel she is overtaking (vessel B), that at night she (vessel A) would be able to see only the sternlight of vessel B but neither of her sidelights . In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B).

Titre: Relative bearing of overtaking vessel is close to STBD 112.5°
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing close to STBD 112.5°)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B because she is coming up with vessel B from a direction more than 22.5° abaft her beam. In accordance with Rule 13 (c) (Overtaking), when vessel A is in any doubt as to whether she is overtaking another (vessel B), she (vessel A) shall assume that this is the case and act accordingly. In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B).

Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing close to PORT 112.5°)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B because she is coming up with vessel B from a direction more than 22.5° abaft her beam. In accordance with Rule 13 (c) (Overtaking), when vessel A is in any doubt as to whether she is overtaking another (vessel B), she (vessel A) shall assume that this is the case and act accordingly. In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B).

Titre: Relative bearing of overtaking vessel is PORT 160°
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 160°)

Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B because she is coming up with vessel B from a direction more than 22.5° abaft her beam.
