Titre: Pilot vessel when not engaged on pilotage duty
Scenario: Type of vessel: Pilot vessel when not engaged on pilotage duty
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 29 (b) (Pilot vessels), a pilot vessel when not engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed for a similar vessel of her length.

Titre: A vessel under 12 m aground - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of less than 12 m in length aground Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 30 (f) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel of less than 12 m in length, when aground, shall not be required to exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 30 (d) (i) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground).

Titre: Sound signals of a vessel over 12 m and under 20 m aground in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel of 12 m or more but less than 20 m in length aground Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (i) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a vessel of 12 m or more but less than 20 m in length shall not be obliged to give the bell signals prescribed in Rule 35 (h) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ). However, if she does not, she shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.
Commentaires: As a vessel of 12 m or more but less than 20 m in length is obliged to carry a whistle only, an efficient sound signal may be sounded by a whistle .

Titre: A seaplane
Scenario: Type of vessel: Seaplane
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 31 (Seaplanes), where it is impracticable for a seaplane to exhibit lights and shapes of the characteristics or in the positions prescribed in the Rules of this Part she shall exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar in characteristics and position as is possible.

Titre: An air-cushion vessel when operating in the non-displacement mode - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Air-cushion vessel underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 23 (b) (Power-driven vessels underway ), an air-cushion vessel when operating in the non-displacement mode shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 23 (a) (Power-driven vessels underway ), exhibit an all-round flashing yellow light.

Titre: A power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow under 200 m - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow does not exceed 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 24 (a) (Towing and pushing), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23 (a)(i) or (a)(ii) (Power-driven vessels underway ), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights ; (iii) a sternlight ; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight . In accordance with Rule 24 (e) (Towing and pushing), a vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in Rule 24 (g) (Towing and pushing), shall exhibit: (i) sidelights ; (ii) a sternlight .

Titre: A vessel proceeding along the course of a narrow channel or fairway
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are meeting in narrow channel
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 9 (a) ( Narrow channels ), a vessel (vessel A and vessel B) proceeding along the course of a narrow channel or fairway shall keep as near to the outer limit or the channel or fairway which lies on her starboard side as is safe and practicable.

Titre: Sailing in traffic separation schemes
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (b)(i) (Traffic separation schemes), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall proceed in the appropriate traffic lane in the general direction of traffic flow for that lane. In accordance with Rule 10 (b)(ii) (Traffic separation schemes), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall so far as practicable keep clear of a traffic separation line or separation zone.
Commentaires: Elements of traffic separation schemes: (i) traffic lane, (ii) direction of traffic flow for the lane, (iii) separation zone or line, (iv) inshore traffic zone.

Titre: The compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 054°) No change in bearing taken at interval of time, CPA=0
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 7 ( Risk of collision ), risk of collision shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change.
Commentaires: If the bearing (compass or relative) taken visually or with radar at interval of time does not appreciable change, than the risk of collision shall be deemed to exist. How often to take bearing from other vessel depends on situation (range between vessels, vessels relative speed, area of navigation, vessels characteristics, navigational equipment, visibility). To be able to decide if a risk of collision exists, bearing on the other vessel should be taken as soon as it is sighted and then repeated in appropriate intervals. In open water, bearing should be taken as soon as it comes over the horizon. It is advisable not to wait until the vessel is close before starting to take bearings.

Titre: Joining traffic separation schemes
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme Vessel A is joining a traffic lane at a termination of the lane Vessel B is joining a traffic lane from side
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (b)(iii) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel (vessel A) using a traffic separation scheme shall normally join a traffic lane at the termination of the lane. In accordance with Rule 10 (b)(iii) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel (vessel B) using a traffic separation scheme when joining from either side shall do so at as small an angle to the general direction of traffic flow as practicable.

Titre: Leaving traffic separation schemes
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme Vessel A is leaving a traffic lane at a termination of the lane Vessel B is leaving traffic lane from side
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (b)(iii) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel (vessel A) using a traffic separation scheme shall normally leave a traffic lane at the termination of the lane. In accordance with Rule 10 (b)(iii) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel (vessel B) using a traffic separation scheme when leaving from either side shall do so at as small an angle to the general direction of traffic flow as practicable.

Titre: Crossing traffic lanes
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel crossing traffic lanes Area: Traffic separation scheme
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (c) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel shall so far as practicable avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to do so shall cross on a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow.
Commentaires: In accordance with Rule 10 (a) (Traffic Separation Schemes), when vessel crossing traffic lanes in accordance with Rule 10 (Traffic separation scheme) and risk of collision with other vessel exists, vessels are not relieved of their obligation under any other rule.

Titre: Vessel shall not use an inshore traffic zone
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (d)(i) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel shall not use an inshore traffic zone when she can safely use the appropriate traffic lane within the adjacent traffic separation scheme.

Titre: Vessels under 20 m, sailing vessels and vessels engaged in fishing may use the inshore traffic zone
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel of less than 20 m in length Vessel B: Sailing vessel Vessel C: Vessel engaged in fishing Area: Traffic separation scheme
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (d)(i) (Traffic separation scheme), vessels of less than 20 m in length, sailing vessels and vessels engaged in fishing may use the inshore traffic zone.

Titre: Vessel may in some situations use an inshore traffic zone
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (d)(ii)(Traffic separation scheme), a vessel may use an inshore traffic zone when en route to or from a port, offshore installation or structure, pilot station or any other place situated within the inshore traffic zone, or to avoid immediate danger.

Titre: Action taken by a vessel which detects by radar alone the presence of another vessel
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Visibility: Restricted (vessels are not in sight of one another) Vessel A detects by radar alone the presence of vessel B Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 053°)
Reference_Regle: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility ) Rule 7 ( Risk of collision )
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 19 (d) (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility ), a vessel which detects by radar alone the presence of another vessel shall determine if a close-quarters situation is developing and/or risk of collision exists. If so, she shall take avoiding action in ample time, provided that when such action consists of an alteration of course, so far as possible the following shall be avoided: (i) an alteration of course to port for a vessel forward of the beam, other than for a vessel being overtaken; (ii) an alteration of course towards a vessel abeam or abaft the beam. In accordance with Rule 7 (b) ( Risk of collision ), proper use shall be made of radar equipment if fitted and operational, including long-range scanning to obtain early warning of risk of collision and radar plotting or equivalent systematic observation of detected objects.

Titre: A WIG craft when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: WIG craft Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 23 (c) (Power-driven vessels underway ), a WIG craft only when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 23 (a) (Power-driven vessels underway ), exhibit a high intensity all-round flashing red light.

Titre: A power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow over 200 m - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 24 (a) (Towing and pushing), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23 (a)(i) or (a)(ii) (Power-driven vessels underway ), three masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights ; (iii) a sternlight ; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight . In accordance with Rule 24 (e) (Towing and pushing), a vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in Rule 24 (g) (Towing and pushing), shall exhibit: (i) sidelights ; (ii) a sternlight .

Titre: A vessel entering a separation zone or crossing a separation line in case of emergency
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel , proceeding in appropriate traffic lane Vessel B: power-driven vessel , proceeding in appropriate traffic lane Vessel C: power-driven vessel , crossing traffic lanes Area: Traffic separation scheme Vessel A and vessel C are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel B is overtaking vessel A
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (e)(i) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel, other than a crossing vessel, or a vessel joining or leaving a lane shall not normally enter a separation zone or cross a separation line except in cases of emergency to avoid immediate danger.

Titre: A vessel engaged in fishing entering a separation zone or crossing a separation line
Scenario: Vessel A: Vessel engaged in fishing Area: Traffic separation scheme
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (e)(ii) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel, other than a crossing vessel, or a vessel joining or leaving a lane shall not normally enter a separation zone or cross a separation line except to engage in fishing within a separation zone.

Titre: A vessel navigating in areas near the terminations of traffic separation schemes
Scenario: Vessel navigating in areas near the terminations of traffic separation scheme Area: Traffic separation scheme
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (f) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel navigating in areas near the terminations of traffic separation schemes shall do so with particular caution.

Titre: A vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any vessel following a traffic lane
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Vessel engaged in fishing Area: Traffic separation scheme
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (i) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any vessel following a traffic lane.

Titre: A vessel under 20 m or a sailing vessel shall not impede the safe passage of a power-driven vessel following a traffic lane
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Vessel C: Vessel of less than 20 meters in length Vessel D: Sailing vessel Area: Traffic separation scheme
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (j) (Traffic separation scheme), a vessel of less than 20 m in length (vessel C) shall not impede the safe passage of a power-driven vessel following a traffic lane. In accordance with Rule 10 (j) (Traffic separation scheme), a sailing vessel (vessel D) shall not impede the safe passage of a power-driven vessel following a traffic lane.

Titre: A WIG craft
Scenario: Type of vessel: WIG craft
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 31 (Seaplanes), where it is impracticable for a WIG craft to exhibit lights and shapes of the characteristics or in the positions prescribed in the Rules of this Part she shall exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar in characteristics and position as is possible.

Titre: Sound signals of a pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty making way through the water in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty making way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (k) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a pilot vessel when engaged on pilotage duty may in addition to the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (a) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ) sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts.

Titre: Sound signals of a pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty underway but stopped and making no way through the water in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty underway but stopped and making no way through the water Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (k) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a pilot vessel when engaged on pilotage duty may in addition to the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (b) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ) sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts.

Titre: Sound signals of a pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty at anchor in restricted visibility
Scenario: Type of vessel: Pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty at anchor Visibility: In or near an area of restricted visibility , weather by day or night
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 35 (k) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), a pilot vessel when engaged on pilotage duty may in addition to the signals prescribed in Rule 35 (g) (Sound signals in restricted visibility ) sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts.

Titre: Safe speed
Scenario: Visibility: Restricted (vessels not in sight of one another) Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility - safe speed
Reference_Regle: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility ) Rule 6 ( Safe speed )
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 19 (b) (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility ), every vessel shall proceed at a safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility . A power-driven vessel shall have her engines ready for immediate manoeuvre. In accordance with Rule 6 ( Safe speed ), every vessel shall at all times proceed at a safe speed so that she can take proper and effective action to avoid collision and be stopped within a distance appropriate to the prevailing circumstances and conditions.

Titre: Complying with the Rules of Section I of Part B
Scenario: Visibility: Restricted (vessels not in sight of one another)
Reference_Regle: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility )
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 19 (c) (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility ), every vessel shall have due regard to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility when complying with the Rules of section I of part B.
Commentaires: In conducting of vessels in restricted visibility every vessel shall have due regard in complying with Rules of section I of part B: - Rule 4 (Application) - Rule 5 ( Look-out ) - Rule 6 ( Safe speed ) - Rule 7 ( Risk of collision ) - Rule 8 ( Action to avoid collision ) - Rule 9 ( Narrow channels ) - Rule 10 (Traffic separation schemes)

Titre: Action taken by a vessel which detects by sound signal the presence of another vessel
Scenario: Visibility: Restricted (vessels are not in sight of one another) Vessel detects by sound signal the presence of another vessel
Reference_Regle: Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility ) Rule 35 (Sound signals in restricted visibility )
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 19 (e) (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility ), except where it has been determined that a risk of collision does not exist, every vessel which hears apparently forward of her beam the fog signal of another vessel, or which cannot avoid a close-quarters situation with another vessel forward of her beam, shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course. She shall if necessary take all her way off and in any event navigate with extreme caution until danger of collision is over. In accordance with Rule 35 (Sound signals in restricted visibility ), in or near an area of restricted visibility , whether by day or night, the signals prescribed in Rule 35 shall be used.

Titre: Overtaking situation (relative bearing of overtaking vessel is 180°) - altering course to starboard
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B on her starboard side Vessel A is astern of vessel B (relative bearing STBD/PORT 180°).
Reference_Regle: Rule 13 (Overtaking situation) Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking situation), a vessel (vessel A) shall be deemed to be overtaking when coming up with another vessel (vessel B) from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam. In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking situation), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of Part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other vessel (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (Vessel B). In accordance with Rule 13 (d) (Overtaking situation), any subsequent alteration of the bearing between the two vessels shall not make the overtaking vessel (Vessel A) a crossing vessel within the meaning of these Rules or relieve her (Vessel A) of the duty of keeping clear of the overtaken vessel (Vessel B) until she is finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel), every vessel (vessel A) which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel (vessel B) shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

Titre: A sailing vessel sailing in a narrow channel or fairway
Scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 9 (b) ( Narrow channels ), a sailing vessel (vessel A) shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway (vessel B).

Titre: A vessel engaged in fishing in a narrow channel or fairway
Scenario: Vessel A: vessel engaged in fishing Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 9 (c) ( Narrow channels ), a vessel engaged in fishing (vessel A) shall not impede the passage of any other vessel navigating within a narrow channel or fairway (vessel B).

Titre: A vessel intending to overtake another in a narrow channel or fairway on her starboard side
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A is intending to overtake vessel B on her starboard side
Reference_Regle: Rule 9 ( Narrow channels ) Rule 13 (Overtaking) Rule 34 (Manoeuvring and warning signals)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow channels ), in a narrow channel or fairway when overtaking can take place only if the vessel to be overtaken (vessel B) has to take action to permit safe passing, the vessel intending to overtake (vessel A) shall indicate her intention by sounding the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34 (c)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals). In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), vessel intending to overtake (vessel A) another (vessel B) shall indicate her intention by the following signals on her whistle : - two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast to mean “I intent to overtake you on your starboard side”. In accordance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow channels ), the vessel to be overtaken (vessel B) shall, if in agreement, sound the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34 (c)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) and take steps to permit safe passing. In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the vessel about to be overtaken (vessel B) shall indicate her agreement by the following signal on her whistle : - one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast in that order. In accordance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow channels ) the vessel to be overtaken (Vessel B) if in doubt as to the intention of crossing vessel (Vessel A), may sound the signals prescribed in Rule 34 (d) (Manoeuvring and warning signals). In accordance with Rule 34 (d) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if the vessel to be overtaken (Vessel B) did not understand the intentions or actions of overtaking vessel (Vessel A), or is in doubt whether sufficient action is being taken by overtaking vessel (Vessel A) to avoid collision, overtaken vessel (Vessel B) shall immediately indicate such doubt by giving at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle . Such signal may be supplemented by a light signal of at least five short and rapid flashes. In accordance with Rule 9 (e)(ii) ( Narrow channels ), Rule 9 ( Narrow channels ) does not relieve the overtaking vessel (Vessel A) of her obligation under Rule 13 (Overtaking). In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking) any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other shall keep out the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B).

Titre: A vessel intending to overtake another in a narrow channel or fairway on her port side
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A is intending to overtake vessel B on her port side

In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), vessel intending to overtake (vessel A) another (vessel B) shall indicate her intention by the following signal on her whistle : - two prolonged blasts followed by one two blasts to mean “I intent to overtake you on your port side”. In accordance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow channels ), the vessel to be overtaken (vessel B) shall, if in agreement, sound the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34 (c)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) and take steps to permit safe passing. In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking) any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other shall keep out the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B).

Titre: A vessel nearing a bend or an area where other vessels may be obscured by intervening obstruction
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are nearing a bend or an area of a narrow channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by intervening obstruction
Reference_Regle: Rule 9 ( Narrow channels ) Rule 34 (Manoeuvring and warning signals)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 9 (f) ( Narrow channels ), a vessel (Vessel A and Vessel B) nearing a bend or an area of a narrow channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by an intervening obstruction shall navigate with particular alertness and caution and shall sound the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34 (e) (Manoeuvring and warning signals). In accordance with Rule 34 (e) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel (Vessel A and Vessel B) nearing a bend or an area of a narrow channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by an intervening obstruction shall sound one prolonged blast .

Titre: The compass bearing of an approaching vessel is increasing
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing Bearing of vessel B taken from vessel A at interval of time is increasing
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 7 ( Risk of collision ), risk of collision shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change.
Commentaires: If the bearing (compass or relative) taken visually or with radar at interval of time does appreciable change (increasing), than the risk of collision shall not be deemed to exist.

Titre: Overtaking situation (relative bearing of overtaking vessel is 180°) - stand-on vessel is altering course to starboard
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is astern of vessel B (relative bearing STBD/PORT 180°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is altering her course to starboard to avoid collision
Reference_Regle: Rule 13 (Overtaking situation) Rule 17 (Action by stand-on vessel)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking situation), a vessel (vessel A) shall be deemed to be overtaking when coming up with another vessel (vessel B) from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam. In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking situation), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of Part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other vessel (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (Vessel B). In accordance with Rule 13 (d) (Overtaking situation), any subsequent alteration of the bearing between the two vessels shall not make the overtaking vessel (Vessel A) a crossing vessel within the meaning of these Rules or relieve her (Vessel A) of the duty of keeping clear of the overtaken vessel (Vessel B) until she is finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 17 (a)(ii) (Action by stand-on vessel), the vessel which shall keep her course and speed (vessel B) may take action to avoid collision by her manoeuvre alone, as soon as it becomes apparent to her that the vessel required to keep out of the way (vessel A) is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules. In accordance with Rule 17 (b) (Action by stand-on vessel), when from any cause, the vessel required to keep her course and speed (vessel B) finds herself so close that collision cannot be avoided by the action of the give-way vessel alone (vessel A), she (vessel B) shall take such action as will best aid to avoid collision. In accordance with Rule 17 (d) (Action by stand-on vessel), Rule 17 does not relieve the give-way vessel (vessel A) of her obligation to keep out of the way.

Titre: Overtaking situation (relative bearing of overtaking vessel is 180°) - altering course to port
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B on her port side Vessel A is astern of vessel B (relative bearing STBD/PORT 180°).
Reference_Regle: Rule 13 (Overtaking situation) Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel)

In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking situation), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of Part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other vessel (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (Vessel B). In accordance with Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel), every vessel (vessel A) which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel (vessel B) shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

Titre: A power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow over 200 m - shapes
Scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel towing, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: Daytime
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 24 (a)(v) (Towing and pushing), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit a diamond shape where it can best be seen. In accordance with Rule 24 (e)(iii) (Towing and pushing), a vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in paragraph (g) of Rule 24 (Towing and pushing), shall exhibit a diamond shape where it can best be seen.

Titre: A pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel pushing a vessel ahead while they are rigidly connected in a composite unit of more than 50 m in length Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 24 (Towing and pushing) Rule 23 ( Power-driven vessel underway )
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 24 (b) (Towing and pushing), when a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 23 ( Power-driven vessel underway ). In accordance with Rule 23 (a), a power-driven vessel underway of more than 50 m in length, shall exhibit: (i) a masthead light forward; (ii) a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one; (iii) sidelights ; (iv) a sternlight .

Titre: A vessel not under command when making way through the water - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel not under command when making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (a) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel not under command shall exhibit: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen; (iii) sidelights and a sternlight .

Titre: A vessel not under command when not making way through the water - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel not under command when not making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (a) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel not under command shall exhibit: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen.

Titre: A vessel not under command - shapes
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel not under command Time of the day: Daytime
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (a) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel not under command shall exhibit: (ii) two balls or similar shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen.

Titre: A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when making way through the water - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (b) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre , except a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations, shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white; (iii) a masthead light or lights, sidelights and a sternlight .

Titre: A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when not making way through the water - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when not making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (b) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre , except a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations, shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white.

Titre: A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre - shapes
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre Time of the day: Daytime
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (b) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre , except a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations, shall exhibit: (ii) three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond.

Titre: A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when at anchor - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre of more than 100 m in length when at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre) Rule 30 (Anchored vessels and vessels aground)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (b) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre , except a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations, shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white; (iv) the light or lights prescribed in Rule 30 (Anchored vessels and vessels aground). In accordance with Rule 30 (a) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen: (i) in the fore part, an all-round white light; (ii) at or near the stern and at a lower level that the light prescribed in subparagraph (i), an all-round white light. In accordance with Rule 30 (c) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel of 100 m and more in length at anchor shall, also use the available working or equivalent lights to illuminate her decks.

Titre: A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when at anchor - shapes
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when at anchor Time of the day: Daytime
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre) Rule 30 (Anchored vessels and vessels aground)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (b) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre , except a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations, shall exhibit: (ii) three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond; (iv) shape prescribed in Rule 30 (Anchored vessels and vessels aground). In accordance with Rule 30 (a)(i) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen, in the fore part, one ball.

Titre: A power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation (restricted to deviate from its course) - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre) Rule 24 (Towing and pushing)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (c) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 24 (a) (Towing and Pushing), exhibit the lights prescribed in subparagraphs (b)(i) of Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre). In accordance with Rule 24 (a) (Towing and pushing), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit: (i) three masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights ; (iii) a sternlight ; (iv) a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight . In accordance with Rule 27 (b) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white.
Commentaires: In accordance with Rule 24 (e) (Towing and pushing), a vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in paragraph (g) of Rule 24 (Towing and pushing), shall exhibit: (i) sidelights ; (ii) a sternlight .

Titre: A power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation (restricted to deviate from its course) - shapes
Scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course, length of the tow exceeds 200 m Time of the day: Daytime
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre) Rule 24 (Towing and pushing)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (c) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course shall, in addition to the shapes prescribed in Rule 24 (a) (Towing and Pushing), exhibit the shapes prescribed in subparagraphs (b)(ii) of Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre). In accordance with Rule 24 (a)(v) (Towing and pushing), a power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit a diamond shape where it can best be seen. In accordance with Rule 27 (b) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall exhibit: (ii) three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond.
Commentaires: In accordance with Rule 24 (e) (Towing and pushing), a vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in paragraph (g) of Rule 24 (Towing and pushing), shall exhibit: (iii) a diamond shape where it can best be seen.

Titre: The compass bearing of an approaching vessel is decreasing
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing Bearing of vessel B taken from vessel A at interval of time is decreasing
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 7 ( Risk of collision ), risk of collision shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change.
Commentaires: If the bearing (compass or relative) taken visually or with radar at interval of time does appreciable change (decreasing), than the risk of collision shall not be deemed to exist.

Titre: Each of two approaching sailing vessels has the wind on a different side
Scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: sailing vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has the wind on the port side Vessel B has the wind on the starboard side
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 12 (a)(i) (Sailing vessels), when two sailing vessel are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision and when each has the wind on a different side, the vessel which has the wind on port side (vessel A) shall keep out of the way of the other (vessel B).

Titre: Two approaching sailing vessels have the wind on the same side
Scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: sailing vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A and vessel B have the wind on the same side Vessel A is at the winward side and vessel B is at the leeward side
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 12 (a)(ii) (Sailing vessels), when two sailing vessel are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision and when both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward (vessel A) shall keep out of the way of the vessel which is to leeward (vessel B). In accordance with Rule 12 (b) (Sailing vessels), the windward side shall be deemed to be the side opposite to that on which the mainsail is carried or, in the case of a square rigged vessel, the side opposite to that on which the largest fore-and-aft sail is carried.

Titre: Two approaching sailing vessels when wind side for one of them cannot be determined with certainty
Scenario: Vessel A: sailing vessel Vessel B: sailing vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has the wind on the port side and sees vessel B to windward and cannot determine with certainty whether vessel B has the wind on the port or on the starboard side
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 12 (a)(iii) (Sailing vessels), when two sailing vessel are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision and if a vessel with the wind on the port side (vessel A) sees a vessel to windward (vessel B) and cannot determine with certainty whether the other vessel (vessel B) has the wind on the port or on the starboard side, she (vessel A) shall keep out of the way of the other (vessel B). In accordance with Rule 12 (b) (Sailing vessels), the windward side shall be deemed to be the side opposite to that on which the mainsail is carried or, in the case of a square rigged vessel, the side opposite to that on which the largest fore-and-aft sail is carried.

Titre: Overtaking situation (relative bearing of overtaking vessel is STBD 160°) - stand-on vessel is altering course to parallel
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 160°) Vessel A which is required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules Vessel B which is the stand-on vessel is altering her course to port to approximately parallel course with vessel A to avoid collision
Reference_Regle: Rule 13 (Overtaking situation) Rule 17 (Action by stand-on vessel)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking situation), a vessel (vessel A) shall be deemed to be overtaking when coming up with another vessel (vessel B) from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam. In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking situation), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of Part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other vessel (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B). In accordance with Rule 13 (d) (Overtaking situation), any subsequent alteration of the bearing between the two vessels shall not make the overtaking vessel (vessel A) a crossing vessel within the meaning of these Rules or relieve her (vessel A) of the duty of keeping clear of the overtaken vessel (vessel B) until she is finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 17 (a)(ii) (Action by stand-on vessel), the vessel which shall keep her course and speed (vessel B) may take action to avoid collision by her manoeuvre alone, as soon as it becomes apparent to her that the vessel required to keep out of the way (vessel A) is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules. In accordance with Rule 17 (d) (Action by stand-on vessel), Rule 17 does not relieve the give-way vessel (vessel A) of her obligation to keep out of the way.

Titre: A sailing vessel underway shall keep out of the way of a vessel not under command
Scenario: Vessel A: Sailing vessel Vessel B: Vessel not under command Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 070°) Vessel A is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 25 (Sailing vessels underway and vessels under oars) Vessel B is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)
Reference_Regle: Rule 18 (Responsibilities between vessels) Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 18 (b)(i) (Responsibilities between vessels), except where Rule 9 ( Narrow channels ), Rule 10 (Traffic separation schemes) and Rule 13 (Overtaking) otherwise require, a sailing vessel underway (vessel A) shall keep out of the way of a vessel not under command (vessel B). In accordance with Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel), every vessel (vessel A) which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel (vessel B) shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Commentaires: In accordance with Rule 18 (b) (Responsibilities between vessels), except where Rule 9 ( Narrow channels ), Rule 10 (Traffic separation schemes) and Rule 13 (Overtaking) otherwise require, a sailing vessel underway shall also keep out of the way of: (ii) a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre ; (iii) a vessel engaged in fishing .

Titre: A vessel engaged in fishing when underway shall keep out of the way of a vessel not under command
Scenario: Vessel A: Vessel engaged in fishing Vessel B: Vessel not under command Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 070°) Vessel A is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 26 (Fishing vessel) Vessel B is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)
Reference_Regle: Rule 18 (Responsibilities between vessels) Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 18 (c)(i) (Responsibilities between vessels), except where Rule 9 ( Narrow channels ), Rule 10 (Traffic separation schemes) and Rule 13 (Overtaking) otherwise require, a vessel engaged in fishing when underway (vessel A) shall keep out of the way of a vessel not under command (vessel B). In accordance with Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel), every vessel (vessel A) which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel (vessel B) shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
Commentaires: In accordance with Rule 18 (c) (Responsibilities between vessels), except where Rule 9 ( Narrow channels ), Rule 10 (Traffic separation schemes) and Rule 13 (Overtaking) otherwise require, a vessel engaged in fishing when underway shall also keep out of the way of: (ii) a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre .

Titre: A power-driven vessel underway shall avoid impeding the safe passage of a vessel constrained by her draught
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Vessel constrained by her draught Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 070°) Vessel A is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 23 (Power-driven vessels underway ) Vessel B is exhibiting signals in compliance with Rule 28 (Vessels constrained by their draught)
Reference_Regle: Rule 18 (Responsibilities between vessels) Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 18 (d)(i) (Responsibilities between vessels), except where Rule 9 ( Narrow channels ), Rule 10 (Traffic separation schemes) and Rule 13 (Overtaking) otherwise require, a power-driven vessel underway (vessel A) shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid impeding the safe passage of a vessel constrained by her draught (vessel B), exhibiting the signals in Rule 28 (Vessels constrained by their draught). In accordance with Rule 18 (d)(ii) (Responsibilities between vessels), a vessel constrained by her draught (vessel B) shall navigate with particular caution having full regard to her special condition. Titre: Risk of collision may exist even when an appreciable bearing change is evident
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel towing another vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing Bearing of vessel B taken from vessel A at interval of time is appreciable changing
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 7 (d)(ii) ( Risk of collision ), risk of collision sometimes exist even when an appreciable bearing change is evident, particularly when approaching a very large vessel or a tow or when approaching a vessel at close range. Comment: The bearing change should be very evident, however sometimes this appreciably large change may not hold true for observations of large vessels. If the bow was being observed and the aspect of the ship changes from end on to a side then the bearing change would be evident but that does not mean that the risk does not exist. Therefore, care should be exercised for large vessels which subtend an angle at the observer, for vessels at close range and vessels in tow.

Titre: A vessel of less than 20 m in length sailing in a narrow channel or fairway
Scenario: Vessel A: vessel of less than 20 m in length Vessel B: power-driven vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway Area: Narrow channel Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 9 (b) ( Narrow channels ), a vessel of less than 20 m in length (vessel A) shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway (vessel B).

Titre: A vessel crossing a narrow channel or fairway
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel , 100 m in length Vessel B: Power-driven vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or a fairway Area: Narrow channel Vessel A is crossing a narrow channel or a fairway Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 9 (d) ( Narrow channels ), a vessel (vessel A) shall not cross a narrow channel or fairway if such crossing impedes the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within such channel or fairway (vessel B). In accordance with Rule 9 (d) ( Narrow channels ), a vessel which can safely navigate only within such channel or fairway (vessel B) may use the sound signal prescribed in Rule 34 (d) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) if in doubt as to the intention of the crossing vessel (vessel A). In accordance with Rule 34 (d) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if a vessel (vessel B) fails to understand the intentions or actions of the other vessel (vessel A), or is in doubt whether sufficient action is being taken by the other vessel (vessel A) to avoid collision, the vessel in doubt (vessel B) shall immediately indicate such doubt by giving at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (d) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), sound signal may be supplemented by a light signal of at least five short and rapid flashes.

Titre: A vessel intended to be overtaken in a narrow channel or fairway does not agree with intention of overtaking vessel
Scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: Narrow channel Vessel A is intending to overtake vessel B on her starboard side Vessel B does not agree with intention of vessel A
Reference_Regle: Rule 9 ( Narrow channels ) Rule 34 (Manoeuvring and warning signals)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow channels ), in a narrow channel or fairway when overtaking can take place only if the vessel to be overtaken (vessel B) has to take action to permit safe passing, the vessel intending to overtake (vessel A) shall indicate her intention by sounding the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34 (c)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals). In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), vessel intending to overtake (vessel A) another (vessel B) shall indicate her intention by the following signals on her whistle : - two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast to mean “I intent to overtake you on your starboard side”. In accordance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow channels ), the vessel to be overtaken (vessel B), if in doubt as to the intention of overtaking vessel, may sound the signals prescribed in Rule 34 (d) (Manoeuvring and warning signals). In accordance with Rule 34 (d) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if a vessel (vessel B) fails to understand the intentions or actions of the other vessel (vessel A), or is in doubt whether sufficient action is being taken by the other vessel (vessel A) to avoid collision, the vessel in doubt (vessel B) shall immediately indicate such doubt by giving at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle . Titre: Head-on situtation (one of the vessels which are required to alter their course to starboard is not taking appropriate action)
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is meeting vessel B on reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B right ahead (relative bearing 000°) Vessel A which is required to alter her course to starboard is not taking appropriate action
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 14 (b) (Head-on situation), head-on situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel (vessel A) sees the other (vessel B) ahead and by night she could see the masthead lights of the other in a line and/or both sidelights and by day she observes the corresponding aspect of the other vessel. In accordance with Rule 14 (a) (Head-on situation), when two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision each shall alter her course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other. In accordance with Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel), vessels A and B which are both directed to keep out of the way of each other shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear. Comment: As vessel A which is required to alter her course to starboard is not taking appropriate action, vessel B may alter her course to starboard and such alteration of course will results in passing at a safe distance. In such case the alteration of course of vessel B shall be greater than in case when both vessels would alter their course in accordance with Rule 14 (a) (Head-on situation).

Titre: Overtaking situation (relative bearing of overtaking vessel is STBD 130°) - altering course to port
Scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel B has vessel A on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 130°) Vessel A is altering course to port to overtake vessel B on her port side
Reference_Regle: Rule 13 (Overtaking situation) Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking situation), a vessel (vessel A) shall be deemed to be overtaking when coming up with another vessel (vessel B) from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam. In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking situation), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of Part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other vessel (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B). In accordance with Rule 13 (d) (Overtaking situation), any subsequent alteration of the bearing between the two vessels shall not make the overtaking vessel (vessel A) a crossing vessel within the meaning of these Rules or relieve her (vessel A) of the duty of keeping clear of the overtaken vessel (vessel B) until she is finally past and clear. In accordance with Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel), every vessel (vessel A) which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel (vessel B) shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

Titre: A power-driven vessel towing alongside - lights

Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 24 (c) (Towing and pushing), a power-driven vessel when towing alongside, except in the case of a composite unit, shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23 (a)(i) or (a)(ii) (Power-driven vessels underway ), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights ; (iii) a sternlight . In accordance with Rule 24 (f)(ii) (Towing and pushing), a vessel being towed alongside shall exhibit a sternlight and at the forward end, sidelights .

In accordance with Rule 24 (g)(i) (Towing and pushing),an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel being towed, shall exhibit one all-round white light at or near the forward end and one at or near the after end.

Titre: A vessel engaged in underwater operations (restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, making way through the water, an obstruction exists on her port side) - lights
Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, making way through the water and an obstruction exists on her port side Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (d) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel engaged in underwater operations, when restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, shall exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 27 (b)(i) and (iii) and shall in addition, when an obstruction exists, exhibit: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists; (ii) two all-round green lights in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white; (iii) a masthead light or lights, sidelights and a sternlight .

Reference_Regle: Rule 10 (Traffic separation schemes) Rule 13 (Overtaking situation) Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 10 (a) (Traffic separation schemes), Rule 10 applies to traffic separation schemes adopted by the Organization and does not relieve any vessel of her obligation under any other rule. In accordance with Rule 10 (b)(i) (Traffic separation schemes), a vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall proceed in the appropriate traffic lane in the general direction of traffic flow for that lane. In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B). In accordance with Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel), every vessel (vessel A) which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel (vessel B) shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre) Rule 23 (Power-driven vessels underway )
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (f) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations shall in addition to the lights prescribed for a power-driven vessel in Rule 23 (Power-driven vessels underway ), exhibit three all-round green lights. One of these lights shall be exhibited near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. These lights indicate that it is dangerous for another vessel to approach within 1000 m of the mine clearance vessel. In accordance with Rule 23 (a) (Power-driven vessels underway ), a power-driven vessel underway shall exhibit: (i) a masthead light forward; (ii) a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one; (iii) sidelights ; (iv) a sternlight .

Scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in mine clearance operations of more than 50 m in length but less than 100 m in length at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
Reference_Regle: Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre) Rule 30 (Anchored vessels and vessels aground)
Application_Regle: In accordance with Rule 27 (f) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations shall in addition to the lights prescribed for a vessel at anchor in Rule 30 (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), exhibit three all-round green lights. One of these lights shall be exhibited near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. These lights indicate that it is dangerous for another vessel to approach within 1000 m of the mine clearance vessel. In accordance with Rule 30 (a) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen: (i) in the fore part, an all-round white light; (ii) at or near the stern and at a lower level that the light prescribed in subparagraph (i), an all-round white light.
